<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
```c
int metal_generic_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;

	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W) {
			metal_cache_flush(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
		}
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
	}

	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
...
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_W 2
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to or otherwise modified in this function. Specific reasoning:
- bus and device are only cast to void to suppress unused-parameter warnings ((void)bus; (void)device;). This does not modify the parameters.
- dir is only compared (if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W)) and never assigned to; no modification.
- sg_out and sg_in are not reassigned (no statements like sg_out = ... or sg_in = ...). The call memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, ...) modifies the objects pointed to by sg_out/sg_in, which is explicitly permitted by the rule (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but not the pointer itself).
- nents_in is read but never written to; it is returned, not modified.
- The loop index i is a local variable; operations like sg_out[i].virt and calls to metal_cache_flush/metal_cache_invalidate modify memory reachable via the pointer parameters, not the pointer parameters themselves.
Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
